title: 111_hr1799
content:
The Act titled "Safe and Efficient Transportation Act of 2009" increases weight limitations for certain vehicles. The "Safe and Efficient Transportation Act of 2009" amends Section 127 of title 23, United States Code to allow states to authorize vehicles with specific axle and weight requirements to operate on Interstate System routes. The "Safe and Efficient Transportation Act of 2009" allows states to authorize vehicles with specific axle and weight requirements to operate on Interstate System routes. Vehicles must not exceed 97,000 pounds gross weight and 51,000 pounds for any group of 3 or more axles. Special rules apply, including exceptions for certain states and the possibility of exceeding axle weight requirements by up to 2,000 pounds. The "Safe and Efficient Transportation Act of 2009" allows states to authorize vehicles with specific axle and weight requirements to operate on Interstate System routes. States must approve this by statute and submit an annual report to the Secretary if authorizing such vehicles on highway routes. The "Safe and Efficient Transportation Act of 2009" allows states to authorize vehicles on highway routes with specific operating requirements and weight limits. States must provide safety statistics, including vehicle miles traveled data, and conduct 5-year assessments after authorizing vehicle operations. The State's annual report must include an assessment of the impacts of authorized vehicles on pavement and bridge maintenance costs. The Secretary will make this information available to the public. The operation of authorized vehicles may be terminated on a specific route if it poses an unreasonable safety risk. The Secretary may use safety data for analysis. States won't have highway funding reduced if they allow certain vehicles on the Interstate System. SEC. 3. SAFE AND EFFICIENT VEHICLE BRIDGE INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM. The Safe and Efficient Vehicle Bridge Infrastructure Improvement Program is established under Chapter 1 of title 23, United States Code. The Secretary will apportion funds to eligible states from the Safe and Efficient Vehicle Trust Fund for bridge infrastructure improvements based on vehicle miles traveled. The Safe and Efficient Vehicle Bridge Infrastructure Improvement Program allocates funds to eligible states based on vehicle miles traveled on Interstate System highways. States must use the apportioned funds for bridge projects eligible for assistance under section 144 for replacement or rehabilitation. The Safe and Efficient Vehicle Trust Fund provides contract authority for eligible states to authorize vehicles on the Interstate System. SEC. 4. OVERWEIGHT VEHICLE TAX. Imposes a tax on certain overweight vehicles using highways. The tax rate is based on vehicle weight. Effective for taxable periods after enactment.

SEC. 5. SAFE AND EFFICIENT VEHICLE TRUST FUND. Provides contract authority for eligible states to authorize vehicles on the Interstate System. SEC. 5. SAFE AND EFFICIENT VEHICLE TRUST FUND. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish a trust fund for safe and efficient vehicles. The Safe and Efficient Vehicle Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by appropriations and taxes under section 4481(g). Amounts in the fund are available for expenditures starting one year after the enactment of the Act. The Safe and Efficient Vehicle Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by appropriations and taxes under section 4481(g). Starting one year after the Act's enactment, projects eligible for assistance under section 144 of title 23, United States Code, can access the fund. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to accommodate this change. The Safe and Efficient Vehicle Trust Fund, established in the Treasury of the United States, will be funded by appropriations and taxes. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will take effect on the enactment date of this Act.
